channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: For Years, Two Men Shuttled Messages Between Israel and Hamas. No Longer.
item.description: Since 2006, Gershon Baskin, an Israeli peace activist, and Ghazi Hamad, a Hamas official, maintained a secret back channel between Gaza and Israel. Then Oct. 7 happened.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gershon Baskin, an Israeli human rights activist, forged a relationship with a Hamas spokesman that for years served as an informal back channel between the group and Israel.

item.title: After Earthquake, Morocco Debates How to Rebuild
item.description: Experts say the government should preserve cultural and architectural heritage, while also building disaster-resistant homes. In the meantime, residents are living in tents and in limbo.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Agadir Oufella, a fortress in Morocco, was damaged during an earthquake in 1960 but has been restored more recently.

item.title: In Hitler’s Birthplace, Soul-Searching Over a Poisonous Past
item.description: The Austrian government is turning the house where Hitler was born into a police station. But many think it should be used instead to teach essential lessons about history.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:credit: Marylise Vigneau for The New York Times

item.title: Javier Milei vs. Sergio Massa in Argentina’s Election: What to Know
item.description: On Sunday, voters will choose whether to elect a far-right libertarian, Javier Milei, or the center-left economy minister, Sergio Massa.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Javier Milei, left, and Sergio Massa during a debate in Buenos Aires. Polls suggest Sunday’s race is a dead heat.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War Turns Gaza Into a ‘Graveyard’ for Children
item.description: Thousands of children have been killed in the enclave since the Israeli assault began, officials in Gaza say. The Israeli military says it takes “all feasible precautions” to avoid civilian deaths.
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for treatment at Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: Swedish Soccer Prioritized Fans Over Finances. Now, Business Is Booming.
item.description: While most of Europe’s leagues engage in a Sisyphean quest to source as much money as possible, Sweden has chosen a different model. But its rewards come with risk.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Betina Garcia for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Malmo, the Swedish soccer team, set off so many flares during the season finale against Elfsborg this month that the match had to be stopped for 30 minutes.

item.title: The Invisible War in Ukraine Being Fought Over Radio Waves
item.description: Using electromagnetic waves to flummox and follow smarter weapons has become a critical part of the cat-and-mouse game between Ukraine and Russia. The United States, China and others have taken note.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Aaron Krolik
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A visualization of the rapidly-changing frequencies of the Himera military radio, which features signal-hopping technology that makes it difficult to jam.

item.title: Taylor Swift Fan Falls Fatally Ill at Brazil Concert Amid Heat
item.description: Many fans fell sick at the show, where temperatures broke records and concertgoers complained of a lack of water. The pop star postponed Saturday’s show.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Leonardo Coelho and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:description: Taylor Swift fans waiting in line for the artist’s Saturday show in Rio de Janeiro. Ms. Swift eventually postponed the show because of the sweltering heat in the city.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israel Says Video Shows Hamas Tunnel Under Besieged Hospital
item.description: Videos released by the Israeli military show a tunnel under Al-Shifa Hospital and what it described as hostages taken on Oct. 7. The footage is meant to bolster Israel’s contention that Hamas used the hospital and its grounds.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting to collect the bodies of Palestinians killed in airstrikes in Khan Yunis, Gaza, on Saturday.

item.title: Hurricane Otis Shatters Acapulco’s Nautical Backbone
item.description: Hurricane Otis left a trail of destruction and death but inflicted its worst blow on the yacht crews and other boat workers who are a pillar of the tourism industry.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Damaged boats seen washed ashore this month in Acapulco, Mexico.

item.title: Europe Moves to Fill Weapons Gap Amid Doubts About U.S. Commitment to Ukraine
item.description: Germany, Norway, Britain and others are increasing weapons production to help Kyiv. But the aid may be coming too late as winter looms and Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia stalls.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing at Russian positions in the Kherson region in January.

item.title: ‘It’s Like I Am Blind’: Waiting for Asylum in a British Hotel
item.description: With the contentious Rwanda plan in disarray, experts say the U.K. government should focus on a huge backlog of asylum cases, including 50,000 people in hotels.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Holbeck, one of the most deprived areas in Leeds, England, in September. The country’s northern region has the highest number of asylum seekers being housed in hotels in Britain.

item.title: French Senator Accused of Drugging Fellow Lawmaker
item.description: Joël Guerriau, a centrist representing a region of western France, is under investigation over suspicion that he spiked a colleague’s drink with the intention of sexually assaulting her.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden

item.title: The Battle of Tarawa in Pictures
item.description: The Battle of Tarawa, in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, took a heavy toll on American forces and led to outrage at home.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Maud Bodoukian Meyrant
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Marines take cover from Japanese fire after making it ashore to Betio, a small, strategic island that was the site of a well-documented and brutal battle in 1943.

item.title: Shakira Reaches Deal in Spanish Tax Fraud Trial
item.description: Prosecutors had charged the pop star with failing to pay 14.5 million euros in income taxes. Her trial had been set to begin on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Shakira outside court in Barcelona, Spain, on Monday. She had been accused of six counts of tax fraud.

item.title: Ukraine Soldiers on the Front Line
item.description: Ukraine is facing continual eastern assaults from Russian forces at a bloody cost for both sides, even as the lines on the map barely move.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Between Israelis and Palestinians, a Lethal Psychological Chasm Grows
item.description: In a conflict marked by complete incomprehension on both sides, the ability to see each other as human has been lost.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli security forces looking on as Palestinians prayed in Jerusalem in October. Nearby is a site sacred to both Jews and Muslims that has been one focus of tensions over the years.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: The latest from the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: A Big Year for India on the Global Stage Ends in Cricket Heartbreak
item.description: A dominant World Cup run closes with a loss to Australia in the final, a symbol of how far India has come and how far it still has to go.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: About 100,000 fans watched India and Australia in the Cricket World Cup final at Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad on Sunday.

item.title: Gaza Infants Evacuated From Al-Shifa Hospital
item.description: U.N. officials said 31 premature babies in precarious health were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital to a hospital further south in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Vivek Shankar, Isabel Kershner and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A Palestinian medic caring for premature babies who were taken to a hospital in the southern Gaza Strip on Sunday from Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: Argentina Elects Javier Milei in Victory for Far Right
item.description: Argentina’s next president is a libertarian economist whose brash style and embrace of conspiracy theories has parallels with those of Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Javier Milei, left, with his sister and campaign manager, Karina Milei, at his victory rally in Buenos Aires on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Babies Evacuated From Al-Shifa
item.description: Plus: A woman’s unconventional escape in India.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A Palestinian medic caring for premature babies who were taken to a hospital in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Sunday from Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Encounters Trouble in Brazil
item.description: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour broke records in North America, but has faced tragedy and mishaps during a three-day stretch of concerts in Rio de Janeiro.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch, Flávia Milhorance and Leonardo Coelho
item.media:description: Taylor Swift performing in Inglewood, Calif., in August. A concertgoer died in the extreme heat during Swift’s concert on Friday in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Karel Schwarzenberg, Renegade Czech Prince and Politician, Dies at 85
item.description: Popular with the Czech public for quietly subverting the aristocracy, he served twice as foreign minister and ran for president in 2013.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: 31 Premature Babies at Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza Are Evacuated
item.description: The 31 babies will be taken to Egypt for treatment, officials say. Israel’s push to seize Al-Shifa Hospital and a lack of power led doctors to warn that the infants were at particular risk.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: A Palestinian medic caring for premature babies who were taken to a hospital in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Sunday from Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: At Least 24 People Killed in Strike on Gaza School Used as a Shelter, UN Says
item.description: Nearly 7,000 people were sheltering at the school, according to the United Nations. Another school had been struck on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency

item.title: Surviving War in Gaza, One Text Message at a Time
item.description: Every morning, Ahmed Mansour, a Palestinian filmmaker in the U.S., texts his family in Gaza to check if they are still alive. Israel’s siege on the territory has caused widespread communication blackouts, making it difficult for him to reach his parents and siblings.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar, Emily Rhyne and Noah Throop
item.media:credit: Mona El-Naggar, Emily Rhyne and Noah Throop/The New York Times

item.title: Viktor Belenko, Who Defected to the West in a Jet Fighter, Dies at 76
item.description: Among the highest-profile figures to flee the Soviet Union, he brought with him a secret weapon and firsthand experience behind the Iron Curtain.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Patients and Workers Leave Gaza Hospital Days After Israeli Raid
item.description: Some said they were ordered to evacuate Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City. The military said it had agreed to a request by the hospital director to help people leave safely.
item.dc:creator: Ameera Harouda, Aaron Boxerman and Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers from the Seventh Brigade on the grounds of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City on Thursday.

item.title: For Survivors of Trance Party Attacked by Hamas, New Center Helps With Healing
item.description: For some who had taken psychedelics at the event, the traumatic effects may have been compounded. A group of caregivers joined together to help.
item.dc:creator: Gal Koplewitz
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of survivors from a trance event at which Hamas killed scores of partygoers on Oct. 7 have been coming to a treatment center in central Israel as they grapple with the psychological aftermath.

item.title: Is Israel’s Military Strategy to Eradicate Hamas Working?
item.description: Israel is making progress in ground control of Gaza, but it has not vanquished Hamas or freed most of the hostages. And international condemnation of civilian casualties is growing.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: A mobile artillery unit firing from the Israeli side of the Israel-Gaza border on Wednesday.

item.title: Colombia to Sterilize Pablo Escobar’s ‘Cocaine Hippos’
item.description: The drug kingpin brought four hippos to his estate in the 1980s. Officials estimate that about 170 now roam Colombia, and say the population must be controlled to protect the country’s ecosystem.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A hippopotamus, one of about 170 descended from four imported by the drug kingpin Pablo Escobar, on Mr. Escobar’s former Hacienda Nápoles estate in Colombia in April.

item.title: A Thanksgiving Road Map
item.description: We have a plan to help you prepare for the holiday — and stay sane.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Sichynsky

item.title: Single-Use Plastics Ban Overturned by Canadian Court
item.description: Steven Guilbeault, Canada’s environment minister, said the government was “strongly considering” an appeal of the federal court’s ruling.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: The government is reviewing the court’s judgment and “strongly considering an appeal,” the environment minister, Steven Guilbeault, said in a statement posted on X.

item.title: As Bedbug Anxiety Spreads to Asia Exterminators Turn Profits
item.description: Outbreaks in France and South Korea have people across Asia on high alert for bedbugs. Exterminators in the region say business is booming.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: South Korea began a four-week prevention-and-disinfection campaign in dormitories, buses, trains and other public places, including Seoul’s Incheon Airport.

item.title: Chapter 5: An Unlikely Escape Route
item.description: Here was the paradox of being a woman in modern India. Sometimes a path from the oppression of patriarchy was marriage to a man willing to help challenge that system.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall, Amanda Taub, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: Nasreen Parveen, 20, ran away to New Delhi to escape an arranged marriage. Her family eventually followed her.

item.title: Earthquake in Southern Philippines Kills 7
item.description: The 6.7-magnitude earthquake struck near General Santos City, where hundreds were injured, and schools and shopping malls were closed.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: The damaged ceiling of a shopping mall in General Santos City, Philippines, on Saturday, after an earthquake.

item.title: Satellite Images Show a Gaza Water Plant Burned Down Amid Water Crisis
item.description: It was not clear what caused the fire, or how recently the plant had been operating.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl

item.title: Liberia’s President Concedes Election Defeat in a Knife-Edge Vote
item.description: President George Weah, a former soccer star whose administration had weathered accusations of corruption, announced that he had lost his bid for re-election to Joseph Boakai, a 78-year-old former vice president.
item.dc:creator: Clair MacDougall and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Joseph Boakai during a campaign event in Liberia’s capital, Monrovia, in September.

item.title: Israel Says Gaza Hospital Held Hamas Command Center: What We Know So Far
item.description: Military experts say it could take days, weeks or months for Israel to make a definitive case. Or it might never come.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A stone-and-concrete shaft on the grounds of the Al-Shifa Hospital, seen on Thursday.

item.title: APEC Gave a Rare Opportunity to See China’s Xi Up Close
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China is one of the most self-contained Chinese leaders in decades, who reveals next to nothing about his personal life.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Ana Swanson and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping has concentrated his power in China by jailing and retiring political rivals and taking greater control of the civil government and the military.

item.title: Israel Displays Tunnel Shaft at Al-Shifa Hospital and Says It Will Allow In Some Fuel
item.description: The discovery at Al-Shifa Hospital did not seem to settle the question of whether Hamas has been using the complex to hide weapons and command centers, as Israel has said.
item.dc:creator: Philip P. Pan, Patrick Kingsley and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: A stone-and-concrete tunnel shaft with a metal ladder on the grounds of Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Thursday.

item.title: Former Obama and Biden Officials Sign Letter Defending U.S.’s Israel Stance
item.description: The letter drew 137 signatures, fewer than an earlier letter of dissent from Biden administration officials. Organizers say the new letter should carry more weight because it is not anonymous.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: The letter affirms President Biden’s opposition to a cease-fire, challenging demands from hundreds of officials that Israel halt its military offensive in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: A Journey Into Northern Gaza: Ruins, Wreckage and Darkness
item.description: New York Times journalists traveled with an Israeli military convoy to catch a rare glimpse of conditions in wartime Gaza. They saw houses flattened like playing cards and a city utterly disfigured.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers from the Seventh Brigade escorted journalists to see a stone-and-concrete shaft on the grounds of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: Italy’s Giorgia Meloni Visits Tolkien Exhibition in Rome
item.description: Italy’s Culture Ministry has opened a curious show dedicated to the life and works of J.R.R. Tolkien — and perhaps a new front in the culture wars. It’s “beautiful.” Just ask the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: The exhibition included a myriad of Middle-earth-themed objects, including a “Lord of the Rings”-themed pinball machine and sculptures of hobbits.

item.title: Xabi Alonso Isn’t Coming to Save Your Team. Not Yet.
item.description: The patience of Alonso, the Bayer Leverkusen manager, says a lot about him, and just as much about a sport perpetually chasing the next big thing.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Xabi Alonso, top of the Bundesliga but still taking his time.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Has Seized Small Dnipro Foothold After Months of Raids
item.description: The Ukrainian military said it had taken a sliver of Russian-controlled land, a move that might offer some hope but was unlikely to lead to a rapid breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on the bank of the Dnipro River near Kherson, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Everton Docked 10 Points, a Premier League Record, in Financial Case
item.description: The penalty adds to the problems of a team operating under a mountain of debt. It vowed to appeal.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Everton’s points deduction dropped the team to 19th place in the 20-team Premier League.

item.title: Iceland Works to Protect Power Plant as it Awaits a Volcanic Eruption
item.description: As the country prepares for a possible volcanic eruption, it’s working to protect a power plant that serves 30,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A police officer near a crack in the road in Grindavik, Iceland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Celebrity Campaign Shines Spotlight on New Zealand Bird Contest
item.description: An endorsement from the comedian John Oliver led to a spike in votes for the eventual winner, the pūteketeke.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A poster promoting the comedian John Oliver’s campaign for the pūteketeke to be named New Zealand’s Bird of the Century in Wellington, New Zealand.

item.title: Russia Sentences Activist to Penal Colony for Antiwar Notes on Price Tags
item.description: A court sentenced Aleksandra Y. Skochilenko to seven years in a penal colony, in one of the most prominent cases of Russia’s crackdown on wartime dissent.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Aleksandra Y. Skochilenko reacting to the court’s ruling against her in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Thursday.

item.title: A Dying Anticorruption Crusader Considers His Life’s Own Misdeeds
item.description: Chuwit Kamolvisit has enthralled Thailand for decades with revelations of police and political corruption. But his own compromised past, including time as a “super pimp,” clouds his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: A politician known to some as “the godfather of sex,” Chuwit Kamolvisit’s anticorruption efforts have made him a household name in Thailand.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Israel’s search of a major hospital in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Satellite images of the Al-Shifa hospital complex, compiled using photos and videos released by the Israeli military, statements from health officials in Gaza and images from Maxar Technologies.

item.title: In Nagorno-Karabakh, Armenia-Azerbaijan Conflict Leaves Raw Wounds
item.description: While the conflict over the breakaway region of Nagorno-Karabakh concluded with an Azerbaijani victory, resentments simmer on both sides, creating fertile ground for new violence.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gulbeniz Magerramova, 67, left, visiting Shusha, Azerbaijan, for the first time since it was recaptured. “I am happy that we returned, but we lost everything that we had here.”

item.title: Israeli and Palestinian Activists Ask Americans to Take Side of Peace
item.description: Sally Abed, a Palestinian citizen of Israel, and Alon-Lee Green, a Jewish Israeli, found polarization in America over the war in Gaza. They also found longing for a new approach.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sally Abed, 32, and Alon-Lee Green, 35, leaders of Standing Together, an organization that works for peace between Israel and Palestinians, at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: International Court Orders Syria to Stop Torture of Political Opponents
item.description: Human rights experts have estimated that some 14,000 people died from torture or were killed in the prisons run by military intelligence and security forces during Syria’s long civil war.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Syria, which was ordered to stop torturing imprisoned opponents, did not send a representative to the hearing at the International Court of Justice in The Hague.

item.title: Pressure Mounts as Israel Searches Al-Shifa Hospital for Hamas Presence
item.description: The Israeli military said troops had uncovered a Hamas tunnel shaft underneath the Al-Shifa Hospital complex, as well as a vehicle on the hospital grounds packed with weapons.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Al-Shifa Hospital, in northern Gaza, is the enclave’s largest hospital complex.

item.title: Canada Convicts Nathaniel Veltman In Killing Of Muslim Family
item.description: A judge is expected to rule on whether Nathaniel Veltman, 22, also committed terrorism when he rammed his pickup truck into a Muslim family in June 2021.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: The funeral for four members of the Afzaal family, who were killed in 2021 after a man, later identified as a white supremacist, ran them over with his pickup truck.

item.title: For Biden, a Subtle Shift in the Power Balance With China’s Xi Jinping
item.description: For the first time in years, a Chinese leader desperately needed a few things from the United States.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: As President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China met in Woodside, Calif., on Wednesday, Mr. Xi stayed away from the aggressive “wolf warrior” tone he had once encouraged.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Continues to Search Al-Shifa
item.description: Plus accusations of atrocities in Darfur.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A satellite image of Al-Shifa Hospital and its surroundings in Gaza on Saturday.
